| mov ax, 13h
| rowspan="86"| [[3D Shareware v1.34]]
| Most splashes in "3D Shareware v1.34" are related to 1990s popular culture. mov is a command in x86 assembly language. More specifically it refers to setting {{w|Mode 13h}} via the Video Bios software interrupt (A very common mode for video games)
|-
| int 10h
|
|-
| Thousands of colors!
| Only 2019 April Fools splash same as release versions.
|-
| No co-processor required!
| {{w|Co-processor}}<nowiki/>s were used to assist 1990s CPUs for complex computing, such as float calculation and graphic processing. Modern CPUs can calculate float directly and graphic processing is done by the GPU.
|-
| MIDI support coming soon!
| {{w|MIDI}} is a computer music format, most popular in 1990s.
|-
| Available on most BBSes!
| {{w|Bulletin board system|BBS}} is the predecessor of internet forums.
|-
| Too big for tape!
| {{w|Tape}} was one of early data media.
|-
| Don't copy that floppy!
| {{w|Floppy disk}}<nowiki/>s were most popular data medium in 1990s. A reference to the {{w|Don't Copy That Floppy}} software anti-piracy campaign.
|-
| Only 6 years until future!
| 3D Shareware v1.34 was 'released' in 1994, so 6 years before 2000.
|-
| 16-bit!
| Most 1990s computers were 16-bit.
|-
| Powered by Turbo Pascal!
| {{w|Turbo Pascal}} was one of programming language popular in 1990s.
|-
| Program MineCraft;
| Pascal style program header.
|-
| Memory protected!
|
|-
| Not Windows 3.11 compatible!
| {{w|Windows 3.11}} was the newest version of Windows in 1994 outside Mainland China.
|-
| TCP/IP is just fad!
| Ironically, {{w|TCP/IP}} became the basis of internet and hence mainstream web protocols.
|-
| IPX forever!
| {{w|IPX}} was a web protocol popular in the 1990s.
|-
| AT!
| {{w|AT (form factor)|AT}} was the earliest form factor of IBM compatible personal computers.
|-
| September got longer!
| A reference to the {{w|Eternal September}} in 1993.
|-
| Woo rec.games.computer.minecraft!
| rec.games.computer.minecraft is a supposed Minecraft Usenet newsgroup name.
|-
| As seen on teletext!
| {{w|Teletext}} was one of the interactive TV technologies popular in the 1990s.
|-
| Polyphonic (when supported)
| The {{w|PC speaker}} was often used to create the impression of polyphonic music or sound effects in the 1990s.
|-
| Watch out for MineCraft for Workgroups!
| 1990s software often had versions for personal use and workgroups, notably {{W|Windows 3.1#Windows for Workgroups|Windows 3.1's Windows for Workgroups}}.
|-
| "LINUX is obsolete"!
| Ironically, {{W|Linux}} is still used to this day. Linux debuted in late 1991 and gained popularity in the mid-1990s.
|-
| Photorealistic rendering!
| 1990s graphic technology was relatively poor, so "Photorealistic rendering" could be advertising at that time.
|-
| FMVs! (CD-ROM version only)
| {{w|Full motion video}} was a video game narration technique popular in the 1990s.
|-
| Degauss you monitor now!
| {{w|Cathode-ray tube|CRT}} monitors are able to be magnetized and affect display. "Degauss your CRT now!" also about this.
|-
| Perfect for LAN Party!
| Early online gaming was on {{w|Local Area Network|LAN}} networks.
|-
| Compatible with most phones!
| Smartphones were not popular in 1994. This would be referring to phones using Java.
|-
| Visit as at <nowiki>gopher://minecraft.net</nowiki>
| {{w|Gopher_(protocol)|Gopher}} was a web protocol popular in the 1990s.
|-
| Send us a postcard with your highscore!
| [[wiktionary:snail mail|Snail mail]] was still popular in the 1990s.
|-
| Patented exploding barrel technology!
| Barrels would explode in 3D Shareware v1.34.
|-
| Kibo-free!
| Means "Keyboard-free". Ironically, even 3D Shareware v1.34 is mainly controlled by a keyboard.
|-
| Check out my geek code!
| {{w|Geek Code}} was a language style popular in the 1990s.
|-
| 31337!
| Leet of "elite".
|-
| Clbuttic!
| Over censored "Classic", caused by the {{w|Scunthorpe problem}}.
|-
| VIRTUAL REALITY!
| Virtual reality already existed in 1994.
|-
| Also try Another World!
| {{w|Another World (video game)|Another World}} was a platform game released in 1991.
|-
| More dynamic than Myst!
| {{w|Myst}} was a graphic adventure game released in 1993.
|-
| Serious Doom competitor!
| {{w|Doom (1993 video game)|Doom}} was a popular videogame in the 1990s.
|-
| Dune II, but fantasy? Booooring!
| {{w|Dune II}} is widely seen as the first RTS in the world. It is refencing {{w|Warcraft: Orcs & Humans}} indirectly, what is also a early RTS but with a fantasy setting.
|-
| Really? What's next, SimChopper?
| Parody of {{w|SimCity}}.
|-
| Juice may be bad for you!
|
|-
| More impact than Shoemaker‚ÄìLevy!
| {{w|Comet Shoemaker‚ÄìLevy 9}} collided with Jupiter in July 1994.
|-
| From country that brought you Ace of Base!
| {{w|Ace of Base}} is a Swedish band.
|-
| I saw the sign!
| {{w|The Sign (song)|Song by Ace of Base}}, released in late 1993.
|-
| Woo, third place
|
|-
| Two gold, one silver!
|
|-
| Mir is still up there!
|''{{w|Mir}}'' was a Soviet space station that was built in low Earth orbit from 1986-1996, which was later destroyed after falling into the atmosphere in 2001.
|-
| Spielberg on the roll!
| {{w|Steven Spielberg}} is a famous director.
|-
| Clever girl!
| A quotation from the 1993 movie ''{{w|Jurassic Park}}''.
|-
| Square Of Life!
|
|-
| Blocky and Blockier!
|
|-
| Somebody stop me!
| A quotation from the 1994 movie ''{{w|The Mask (1994 film)|The Mask}}''.
|-
| Lord of the Rings movie sucks!

|-
| Wind of Change!
| Song by {{w|Scorpions (band)|Scorpions}}.
|-
| Superman is dead!
| The Comic book event of {{W|The Death of Superman}} was related between the years of 1992 & 1993
|-
| Look at that mullet!
| {{W|Mullet (haircut)|Mullets}} were a popular hairstyle in the 1980s and 1990s.
|-
| What if Greedo shot first?
| There was no "Han shot first" meme in 1994; the remake of A New Hope with the scene came out in 1997.
|-
| Ewoks? What next, talking seahorse!?
| Ewoks is a race from ''{{w|Star Wars}}''.

| My mom says it's nice!

| A reference to the [[wikipedia:Smells Like Teen Spirit|Nirvana song]] of the same name from 1991.

| Grayskull is god in {{w|He-Man and the Masters of the Universe}}.

| A whole new world!
| {{w|A Whole New World}} is a song from the 1992 film Aladdin.

| Party time! Excellent!

| Catchphrase of Michelangelo in {{w|Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles}} (since 1987), as well as {{w|Bart Simpson}} in {{w|The Simpsons}} (since 1990).

| The Year of the Cartridge!
| Cartridges were a popular form of storage media in 1990s.

| Now rated by the ESRB!
| {{w|ESRB}} was founded in 1994.
